abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project's outcome was
            marginally satisfactory. The key lessons learned are: 1)
            Implementation of project across ministries is difficult
            especially when the lines of authority, support
            arrangements, and expectations of interaction between
            ministries are not clearly defined. 2) Components that are
            not consistent with the core purpose of a project should not
            be added. 3) When the ability of one component to achieve
            its objectives is dependent on the success of another, the
            relationship between the components must be considered at
            appraisal and throughout implementation. 4) Decisions to
            extend projects should be made sufficiently in advance to
            allow for continuity of activities and maximum utility of
            the extension. 5) Key stakeholders should be involved from
            project identification. 6) Clear performance indicators
            should be agreed upon at appraisal. 7) Procurement capacity
            should be thoroughly assessed at appraisal, and provisions
            made at that time to address any inadequacies in capacity.
            8) The experience of this project clearly illustrates the
            relationship between intensified supervision and
            implementation progress. 9) A further rationalization of the
            Government's portfolio of projects is required, as
            evidenced by the implementation delays caused by the
            unavailability of the required Government counterpart
            funding. In addition, strengthened financial management and
            the introduction of accountability measures are necessary to
            avoid delays.
